title: Deuteronomy Chapter 14 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Deuteronomy chapter 14 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 14 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Deuteronomy Chapter 14.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 14:1, what are the children of the LORD your God instructed not to do?
options: Cut yourselves or make baldness between your eyes for the dead
Ignore the Levite within your gates
Tithe all the increase of your seed
questions.correctAnswer: Cut yourselves or make baldness between your eyes for the dead
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:1 instructs the children of the LORD not to cut themselves or make baldness between their eyes for the dead.

questions.question: What status does Deuteronomy 14:2 give to the people chosen by the LORD?
options: A peculiar holy people above all nations
questions.correctAnswer: A peculiar holy people above all nations
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:2 says the LORD hath chosen the people to be a peculiar and holy people above all nations on earth.

questions.question: Which animals are listed in Deuteronomy 14:4 as beasts which you shall eat?
questions.correctAnswer: Ox, sheep, and goat
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:4 specifically lists the ox, the sheep, and the goat as the beasts to eat.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 14:7, which of these animals is unclean because it chews the cud but does not divide the hoof?
questions.correctAnswer: Camel
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:7 states the camel chews the cud but does not divide the hoof, making it unclean.

questions.question: Deuteronomy 14:8 declares which animal unclean because it divides the hoof but does not chew the cud?
questions.correctAnswer: Swine
questions.explanation: The swine is unclean because it divideth the hoof yet cheweth not the cud, according to Deuteronomy 14:8.

questions.question: What kind of water creatures are permitted to eat according to Deuteronomy 14:9?
questions.correctAnswer: Those with fins and scales
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:9 states that all that have fins and scales shall be eaten.

questions.question: Which birds are you forbidden to eat according to Deuteronomy 14:12?
questions.correctAnswer: Eagle, ossifrage, and ospray
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:12 lists the eagle, ossifrage, and ospray among birds not to be eaten.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 14:19, what is said about every creeping thing that flieth?
options: It is unclean and shall not be eaten
It is clean and may be eaten
It is reserved for the priests
It is a sign of blessing
questions.correctAnswer: It is unclean and shall not be eaten
questions.explanation: Verse 14:19 declares every creeping thing that flieth is unclean and shall not be eaten.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 14:21 forbid regarding the kid and its mother’s milk?
options: Thou shalt not seethe a kid in his mother's milk
Thou shalt boil a kid in his mother's milk
Thou shalt offer a kid in milk as a sacrifice
Thou shalt drink the milk of a kid
questions.correctAnswer: Thou shalt not seethe a kid in his mother's milk
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:21 forbids seething a kid in his mother's milk.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 14:22, what are you commanded to tithe?
options: All the increase of thy seed from the field
All the fish in the waters
questions.correctAnswer: All the increase of thy seed from the field
questions.explanation: Verse 14:22 commands tithing all the increase of the seed that the field brings forth.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 14:23 instructs to eat the tithe of your produce before the LORD in the place He chooses.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:23 clearly states to eat the tithe before the LORD in the place He chooses.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 14:27 says the Levite has an inheritance with you.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 14:27 specifies the Levite has no part nor inheritance with you and must not be forsaken.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 14:29 says the stranger, fatherless, and widow shall come and be satisfied from the tithes.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:29 states that the Levite, stranger, fatherless, and widow shall eat and be satisfied from the tithes.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Deuteronomy 14:6: 'And every beast that parteth the hoof, and cleaveth the cleft into two claws, and ________ among the beasts, that ye shall eat.'
questions.correctAnswer: cheweth the cud
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:6 specifies beasts that part the hoof and chew the cud are to be eaten.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Deuteronomy 14:25: 'Then shalt thou turn it into money, and bind up the money in thine hand, and shalt go unto the place which the LORD thy God shall ________.'
questions.correctAnswer: choose
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:25 says to go to the place which the LORD thy God shall choose.

medium.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 14 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Deuteronomy Chapter 14 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 14 teach us about holiness and self-discipline in times of grief?
options: Do not cut yourselves or make baldness for the dead
Mourn loudly and make visible signs of sorrow
Flee to the mountains to mourn
questions.correctAnswer: Do not cut yourselves or make baldness for the dead
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:1 instructs God's people not to cut themselves or make baldness between their eyes for the dead, highlighting a call to holiness and self-control even in grief. This reflects obedience and trust in God's sanctifying purpose.

questions.question: What biblical principle about being God's chosen people can encourage perseverance in trials?
options: You are a holy and peculiar people chosen by God
You are to depend on your own strength
You must separate from all nations physically
You are to judge other nations harshly
questions.correctAnswer: You are a holy and peculiar people chosen by God
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:2 reminds believers that they are holy and chosen by God, which encourages perseverance by focusing on their special relationship and purpose in Him, even amid challenges.

questions.question: A believer is uncertain about what foods to choose to honor God. According to Deuteronomy 14, what guideline should they follow regarding animals?
options: Eat animals that part the hoof and chew the cud
Eat any animal that is available
Only eat fish without fins and scales
questions.correctAnswer: Eat animals that part the hoof and chew the cud
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:4-6 specifies that only animals that part the hoof and chew the cud are clean and permissible to eat, teaching obedience in daily living and honoring God through discipline.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 14 instruct believers to practice generosity and care for others in their community?
options: Bring tithes to the Levite, the stranger, the fatherless, and the widow to eat and be satisfied
Keep all produce for personal use only
Give only to those who can repay you
questions.correctAnswer: Bring tithes to the Levite, the stranger, the fatherless, and the widow to eat and be satisfied
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:28-29 commands that the tithe of the increase be shared with Levites and vulnerable groups, teaching generosity, stewardship, and community care as expressions of faith.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 14 teach about integrity and honesty in using tithes when the place of worship is too far?
options: Convert the tithe into money and spend it at the chosen place to rejoice before God
Keep the tithe at home without bringing it to the place of worship
Give the tithe only to the poor at home
Use the tithe for personal luxuries
questions.correctAnswer: Convert the tithe into money and spend it at the chosen place to rejoice before God
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:24-26 encourages believers to faithfully convert and use their tithes appropriately, demonstrating integrity and reverence in worship even when the journey is difficult.

questions.question: A fellow believer struggles with temptation to eat unclean food. What biblical truth from Deuteronomy 14 would help them remain obedient?
options: Eat only animals with fins and scales or that chew cud and have cloven hooves
Eat whatever is available to avoid waste
Focus on external appearance rather than dietary laws
questions.correctAnswer: Eat only animals with fins and scales or that chew cud and have cloven hooves
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:3-10 provides clear dietary laws emphasizing obedience and holiness, which can help believers resist temptation and live in accordance with God's commands.

questions.question: What spiritual discipline does the command to tithe and eat before the LORD help cultivate?
options: Fear of the LORD and continual reverence
questions.correctAnswer: Fear of the LORD and continual reverence
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:22-23 teaches that tithing and eating before the LORD in the chosen place help believers learn to fear and revere God continually, fostering humility and faithfulness.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 14 model hospitality and support for those who serve in ministry?
options: Do not forsake the Levite; provide for him since he has no inheritance
Ignore the Levite and rely on their own means
Expect the Levite to provide for themselves
questions.correctAnswer: Do not forsake the Levite; provide for him since he has no inheritance
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:27 emphasizes supporting the Levite who serves God's people, teaching generosity and respect for spiritual leaders as part of faithful community living.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 14 permits eating animals that chew the cud but do not have cloven hooves.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:7 explains that animals like the camel chew the cud but do not have cloven hooves and are therefore unclean and not to be eaten, illustrating God's standards for holiness.

questions.question: True or False: According to Deuteronomy 14, it is acceptable to eat anything that died of itself.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:21 clearly states that one shall not eat anything that dies of itself but give it to the stranger or sell it, demonstrating obedience and respect for God's law.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Deuteronomy 14 teaches that you shall not seethe a ____ in his mother's milk.
questions.correctAnswer: kid
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:21 prohibits boiling a young goat (kid) in its mother's milk, a command teaching respect for life and God's ordinances.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 14 teach contentment and gratitude through the use of tithes?
options: Use tithes to rejoice with family and the LORD
Save tithes for future needs only
questions.correctAnswer: Use tithes to rejoice with family and the LORD
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:26 encourages spending tithe money joyfully before the LORD with family, promoting gratitude and contentment in God's provision.

questions.question: What lesson about perseverance in faith can be drawn from the command to tithe year by year?
options: Faithfulness in stewardship is continuous and consistent
Focus on giving only at harvest
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness in stewardship is continuous and consistent
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:22 commands tithing all increase year by year, teaching believers the importance of ongoing faithfulness and trust in God's provision over time.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 14, why is it important to learn to fear the LORD always through tithing and worship?
options: So that reverence to God becomes a continual lifestyle
questions.correctAnswer: So that reverence to God becomes a continual lifestyle
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:23 states the purpose of eating the tithe before the LORD is to learn to fear Him always, cultivating a lifelong attitude of reverence and obedience.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 14 guide believers in maintaining spiritual discipline in their daily eating habits?
options: By following God's dietary laws regarding clean and unclean animals
By eating whatever is tasty and available
By fasting every day without exception
By only eating at the temple
questions.correctAnswer: By following God's dietary laws regarding clean and unclean animals
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:3-20 provides clear instructions on clean and unclean foods, encouraging believers to exercise spiritual discipline and obedience in their everyday choices.

hard.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 14 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Deuteronomy Chapter 14.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 14:1, what physical act are the Israelites commanded not to perform as a sign of mourning, which contrasts with pagan mourning customs in the ancient Near East?
questions.correctAnswer: Cutting themselves
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:1 explicitly instructs the Israelites not to cut themselves, a practice common among pagan peoples as a sign of grief, highlighting their distinct identity as God's holy people.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of the Israelites being called a 'peculiar people' in Deuteronomy 14:2, especially in relation to Israel's election among the nations?
questions.correctAnswer: Chosen for holiness and separation
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:2 emphasizes Israel’s election as a people set apart for God’s purposes, which parallels themes of holiness and separation found throughout Leviticus and other Pentateuchal texts.

questions.question: Which of the following animals is listed in Deuteronomy 14 as clean and permissible to eat because it both chews the cud and has a divided hoof?
questions.correctAnswer: Sheep
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:4-6 lists the sheep as a clean animal because it chews the cud and has a divided hoof, aligning with Leviticus 11's dietary laws and symbolizing purity.

questions.question: Why are camels considered unclean according to Deuteronomy 14:7, despite chewing the cud?
options: They do not have a divided hoof
They are associated with pagan rituals
questions.correctAnswer: They do not have a divided hoof
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:7 states camels chew the cud but do not have a divided hoof, which disqualifies them from being clean animals, illustrating the strict dual criteria for clean beasts.

questions.question: What does the prohibition against eating swine and touching their carcass in Deuteronomy 14:8 reflect in the context of Israelite identity and purity laws?
options: Swine are unclean because they do not chew the cud
Swine are sacred to foreign gods
Swine meat was scarce and reserved for priests
questions.correctAnswer: Swine are unclean because they do not chew the cud
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:8 highlights that swine are unclean because they have a divided hoof but do not chew the cud, reinforcing the dual criteria for clean animals and Israel’s call to purity.

questions.question: Which aquatic creatures are permitted for consumption according to Deuteronomy 14:9-10, and how does this dietary rule relate to ancient Near Eastern cultural distinctions?
questions.correctAnswer: Fish with fins and scales
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:9-10 restricts consumption to fish with fins and scales, distinguishing Israel from other cultures that consumed a wider variety of sea creatures, thus marking their holiness.

questions.question: Among the birds listed as forbidden in Deuteronomy 14:12-18, which of the following is included as unclean and why might these birds have been associated with impurity?
questions.correctAnswer: Owl
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:15-16 lists the owl among unclean birds, likely due to its nocturnal scavenging habits, which symbolically associate it with impurity and death in ancient symbolism.

questions.question: True or False: According to Deuteronomy 14:19, all flying creeping creatures are considered clean and may be eaten by the Israelites.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:19 clearly states that every creeping thing that flies is unclean and shall not be eaten, underscoring strict dietary distinctions.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 14:21 command the Israelites regarding animals that die of themselves, and what does this reveal about the social and religious ethics of the community?
options: Do not eat them; give them to strangers or sell them
Eat them quickly before they spoil
questions.correctAnswer: Do not eat them; give them to strangers or sell them
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:21 prohibits eating animals that die naturally, instead instructing to give or sell them to outsiders, emphasizing holiness and separation within the community.

questions.question: What is the significance of the prohibition against boiling a kid in its mother's milk in Deuteronomy 14:21, especially in relation to ancient fertility rituals?
options: It forbids a Canaanite pagan practice
It encourages use of dairy products
questions.correctAnswer: It forbids a Canaanite pagan practice
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:21's prohibition likely condemns a pagan ritual involving milk and meat, emphasizing Israel’s separation from Canaanite fertility rites and idolatrous practices.

questions.question: What is the purpose of tithing according to Deuteronomy 14:22-23, and how does it function as a spiritual discipline for Israel?
options: To learn to fear the LORD always
To accumulate wealth for the priests
questions.correctAnswer: To learn to fear the LORD always
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:23 teaches that tithing and eating before the LORD in the chosen place fosters reverence and continual awareness of God’s provision.

questions.question: If the place where God chooses to set His name is too far, what alternative does Deuteronomy 14:24-26 allow for the tithe, and what does this reveal about flexibility within Israelite law?
options: Convert the tithe into money and spend it at the chosen place
Give the tithe to the Levites directly
questions.correctAnswer: Convert the tithe into money and spend it at the chosen place
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:24-26 provides a practical allowance to convert tithes into money if travel is difficult, reflecting the law’s accommodation of real-life circumstances without compromising worship.

questions.question: Who are included among those to be supported by the tithes stored within the gates as described in Deuteronomy 14:27-29, and what does this indicate about Israelite social justice?
questions.correctAnswer: Levites, strangers, fatherless, and widows
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:27-29 commands that tithes support vulnerable groups, demonstrating the law’s concern for social equity and community care.

questions.question: How does the dietary law in Deuteronomy 14 serve as a typology for later New Testament teachings on clean and unclean, particularly in Acts 10 with Peter's vision?
options: It foreshadows the lifting of dietary restrictions for Gentiles
It relates to temple sacrifice rules
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows the lifting of dietary restrictions for Gentiles
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14’s detailed food laws set the stage for the New Testament’s reinterpretation in Acts 10 where God declares all foods clean, expanding inclusion to Gentiles.

questions.question: In what way does the literary structure of Deuteronomy 14 exhibit parallelism, especially in its lists of clean and unclean animals?
options: By pairing animals with similar traits in contrasting categories
questions.correctAnswer: By pairing animals with similar traits in contrasting categories
questions.explanation: The chapter contrasts animals that chew cud and have divided hooves with those that have only one trait, employing parallelism to clarify clean versus unclean distinctions.

theological.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 14 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Deuteronomy Chapter 14 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 14, why are the Israelites instructed not to cut themselves or make baldness between their eyes for the dead?
options: Because they are the children of the LORD their God
Because it is a sign of mourning for pagans
Because it is unhealthy for the skin
Because it is a tradition of their ancestors
questions.correctAnswer: Because they are the children of the LORD their God
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:1 states that the Israelites are the children of the LORD their God and thus must not imitate pagan mourning customs such as cutting themselves or making baldness. This reflects God's holiness and the distinct identity of His people. Similarly, Leviticus 19:28 forbids cutting the body for the dead, and 1 Corinthians 6:19-20 teaches believers that their bodies are temples of the Holy Spirit, called to holiness.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 14:2 say about the people of Israel in relation to God?
options: They are a holy and peculiar people chosen by the LORD
They are to be separated from all nations strictly
They must conquer all other nations
They are the most powerful nation on earth
questions.correctAnswer: They are a holy and peculiar people chosen by the LORD
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:2 emphasizes that Israel is a holy people chosen by God to be distinct from other nations. This theme is consistent with 1 Peter 2:9 which calls believers a chosen generation and royal priesthood, and Isaiah 43:20-21 which speaks of God's chosen servant people for His glory.

questions.question: Which of the following animals is permitted to be eaten according to Deuteronomy 14?
questions.correctAnswer: Ox
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:4-6 lists animals permitted for consumption, including the ox, which is a clean animal that parts the hoof and chews the cud. The camel, hare, and swine are listed as unclean (Deuteronomy 14:7-8). This clean/unclean distinction is reiterated in Leviticus 11 and is linked to God's holiness (Leviticus 20:24-26). Jesus refers to clean and unclean in Mark 7:18-19 in a spiritual sense, but the dietary laws also reflect God's standards for purity.

questions.question: What is the defining characteristic of fish that the Israelites are allowed to eat?
options: They must have fins and scales
They must be caught in the Jordan River
They must be larger than a cubit
questions.correctAnswer: They must have fins and scales
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:9-10 instructs that fish with fins and scales are clean and may be eaten, while those without these features are unclean. This distinction symbolizes purity and separation (Leviticus 11:9-12). Peter's vision in Acts 10:9-16 challenges this dietary boundary in the context of the Gospel, but the original command reflects God's holiness and order.

questions.question: Which bird is specifically mentioned as unclean and forbidden to eat in Deuteronomy 14?
questions.correctAnswer: Owl
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:15-16 lists the owl among birds that are unclean and not to be eaten. The owl is associated with darkness or desolation (Leviticus 11:13-19). This prohibition underscores God's call for His people to separate from practices associated with evil or defilement (Psalm 102:6).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Deuteronomy 14:21 commands, 'Thou shalt not eat of any thing that _______'
questions.correctAnswer: dieth of itself
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:21 forbids eating animals that die of themselves (carcasses), reflecting God's concern for purity and health. This is echoed in Leviticus 17:15 and Acts 15:20 where abstaining from blood and strangled animals maintains holiness and fellowship.

questions.question: What is the reason given in Deuteronomy 14:21 for not boiling a kid in its mother's milk?
options: It is a command from the LORD because you are a holy people
questions.correctAnswer: It is a command from the LORD because you are a holy people
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:21 concludes with the prohibition against boiling a kid in its mother's milk, linking it to the holiness of God's people. This law symbolizes respect for life and God's provision (Exodus 23:19). The New Testament references this law in Colossians 2:16-17 as part of the ceremonial law fulfilled in Christ.

questions.question: What is the purpose of tithing according to Deuteronomy 14:22-23?
options: To learn to fear the LORD thy God always
To accumulate wealth for the priests
To show superiority over other nations
questions.correctAnswer: To learn to fear the LORD thy God always
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:22-23 teaches that tithing the produce and eating it before the LORD is intended to foster reverence and continual fear of God. This is consistent with Proverbs 3:9-10 and Malachi 3:10, which link tithing with honoring God. Hebrews 12:28 also speaks of serving God with reverence and awe.

questions.question: If the place God has chosen for His name is too far, what does Deuteronomy 14 instruct the Israelites to do with their tithe?
options: Convert it into money and spend it there on what their soul desires
Leave it at home for the Levites
Send it to the priests by caravan
Store it until they can bring it physically
questions.correctAnswer: Convert it into money and spend it there on what their soul desires
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:24-26 instructs that if the place chosen by the LORD is too distant, the tithe should be converted into money and used there to buy food and rejoice before God. This shows God's provision and the joy of worship. It aligns with the principle of heart worship in 2 Chronicles 31:5-6 and the rejoicing in God's presence in Psalm 100.

questions.question: Who are specifically mentioned in Deuteronomy 14:27 as having no inheritance and must not be forsaken?
questions.correctAnswer: The Levite within thy gates
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:27 states that the Levite has no inheritance and must be supported by the people. This reflects God's provision for the priestly tribe to serve Him fully (Numbers 18:20-24). Jesus honors the Levites' role in Luke 1:5, and Hebrews 7 discusses the priesthood in Christ’s fulfillment.

questions.question: At the end of how many years does Deuteronomy 14 instruct the Israelites to bring all the tithe of their increase and lay it up within their gates?
questions.correctAnswer: Three years
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:28 commands bringing the tithe after three years to be stored within the gates for the Levite, stranger, fatherless, and widow to eat. This reflects God's justice and care for the marginalized (Deuteronomy 26:12-13). Jesus teaches generosity and care for the needy in Matthew 25:35-40.

questions.question: Who are the beneficiaries of the tithe stored within the gates as described in Deuteronomy 14:29?
questions.correctAnswer: Levite, stranger, fatherless, and widow
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:29 lists the Levite, stranger, fatherless, and widow as recipients of the stored tithe, showing God's concern for the vulnerable and those who serve Him. This principle is upheld in Psalm 146:9 and James 1:27 emphasizing care for orphans and widows.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 14, which of the following is NOT a reason given for the dietary laws?
options: To distinguish Israel as a holy people
To gain favor with pagan nations
questions.correctAnswer: To gain favor with pagan nations
questions.explanation: The dietary laws in Deuteronomy 14 serve to distinguish Israel as holy (Deuteronomy 14:2), maintain ritual purity (Leviticus 11), and promote holiness (1 Peter 1:15-16). They do not aim to gain favor with pagan nations; rather, they set Israel apart from them. This is consistent with Romans 12:2's call not to conform to the world.

questions.question: What theological theme is highlighted by God choosing Israel as a 'peculiar people' in Deuteronomy 14:2?
options: God's sovereign election and covenant relationship
questions.correctAnswer: God's sovereign election and covenant relationship
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:2's designation of Israel as God's peculiar people emphasizes His sovereign election and covenant relationship. This theme is foundational in Scripture, seen in Genesis 12:2-3, Exodus 19:5-6, and affirmed in 1 Peter 2:9 for the church as God's chosen people.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the ethical dimension of the dietary and tithe laws in Deuteronomy 14?
options: They promote holiness, justice, and care for the marginalized
They are symbolic only without ethical implications
questions.correctAnswer: They promote holiness, justice, and care for the marginalized
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14 combines laws about clean/unclean foods and tithes that promote holiness (Deuteronomy 14:1-2), justice (supporting Levites and strangers), and care for the marginalized (fatherless and widows in 14:29). This ethical concern aligns with Micah 6:8 and James 1:27 emphasizing true religion as holiness and compassion.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 14 reinforce the understanding of God’s holiness?
options: By commanding Israel to be holy and set apart in behavior and diet
By allowing Israel to adopt surrounding nations' customs
questions.correctAnswer: By commanding Israel to be holy and set apart in behavior and diet
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 14:1-2 stresses that Israel must be holy as God is holy, demonstrated through distinct dietary laws and conduct. This reflects the attribute of God's holiness (Isaiah 6:3) and His call to His people in Leviticus 19:2 and 1 Peter 1:15-16 to be set apart.
